question.content:
**This is an excerpt from the Court’s opinion in *Bostock v. Clayton County* (2020).**

Ours is a society of written laws. Judges are not free to overlook plain [[☃ definition 1]] commands on the strength of nothing more than suppositions about intentions or guesswork about expectations. In Title VII, Congress adopted broad language making it illegal for an employer to rely on an employee’s sex when deciding to fire that employee.  We do not hesitate to recognize today a necessary consequence of that legislative choice: An employer who fires an individual merely for being gay or transgender defies the law.

**What method of constitutional interpretation did Justice Gorsuch use in this opinion?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: This type of constitutional interpretation would have had Justice Gorsuch looking at the historical context of the law. Instead, he points out how time has changed the interpretation of this law.

When a judge uses precedent as a constitutional interpretation method, they take rulings in old cases and apply them to new cases. Justice Gorsuch does not refer to previous decisions in this excerpt of the majority opinion.
Justice Gorsuch does not mention the structure of the Constitution or any of its provisions to reach this decision.
Justice Gorsuch takes into account the real-world consequences of this decision. The Court is broadening the protections included in the Civil Rights Act of 1964.
